River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of Storm Babet. Flooding continues.
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the week. Further rainfall is forecast for Thursday, 26/10/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.
Please avoid contact with flood water. Contact your insurance company if you've been flooded and take photographs of any flood damage.
This message will be updated tomorrow (26/10/2023), or as the situation changes

items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as levels on the Lower River Derwent remain high, and are forecast to rise following rainfall associated with Storm Babet and further rainfall today, Thursday 26/10/23. Further rainfall over the Upper Derwent and Rye catchments today will ensure levels will remain high into the weekend as water moves down into the Lower River Derwent Catchment. Low-lying land is most affected, particularly around local roads and low-lying land around Buttercrambe, Elvington and Bielby Beck. Our duty officers are closely monitoring the situation. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We will update this message by 9PM 26/10/23.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  Flooding may affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. We expect river levels to begin falling from 07:00 on Wednesday, 25/10/23. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Wednesday, 24/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee as a result of heavy rainfall from storm Babet. 
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield lane is currently cut off.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of Storm Babet.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Low lying land and the foreshore in the Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, 
East and West Stockwith areas is expected but not overtopping of minor defences onto agricultural land. TW Logistics and Gainsborough Railway 
bridge. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. Avoid contact with flood water.  This message will be updated by 18:00 26/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are continuing to steadily fall at the Shardlow and Willington Cableway river gauges as a result of Storm Babet. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Ingleby, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, the B5008 at Willington, the access frontage at Swarkestone, the A5132 between Willington and Barrow, and Meadow Lane. Further showers are possible over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. Avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated this afternoon, 26/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the East and west Glens has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels remain high but are falling at the Mattersey river gauge as a result of Storm Babet. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including the A631, roads in the Bawtry Viaduct area and Mission West and East areas. No further significant rainfall is forecast.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid contact with flood water.  This message will be updated by 18:00 26/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.message: River levels on the River Went continued to fall overnight and are now below levels of concern. Further showery rain is forecast over the next few days but no further impacts are expected. We do not anticipate we will need to issue any further flood alerts or warnings, however, our incident room remains open and we are closely monitoring the forecast. There may still be standing water in the area so take care, near local watercourses and low-lying land.

This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels have continued to fall in the lower River Rother and there is no longer a threat of further flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Flooding has affected low-lying land near the watercourse, particularly in the Catcliffe area. Further showers are forecast over the next few days, though impacts are expected to be minimal. Our incident room remains open, and we are closely monitoring the forecast.  
Our operational staff have been on site in the Catcliffe and Treeton area, and will continue to monitor the situation today, 25/10/2023.

items.description: River Waring immediately upstream of Stanhope Road
items.message: River levels in the River Waring have being falling steadily today, Wednesday 25th October and we do not expect any further flooding to properties. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days and the rivers will remain reactive to any future rainfall due to the saturated catchments.

items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

River levels continue to fall but remain elevated on the River Don. This alert remains in force as there is water on low lying land and in washlands adjacent to the rivers. Pumping operations are ongoing in the area. Further showery rain is forecast over the next few days but no further impacts are expected. We do not anticipate we will need to issue any further flood warnings.
The Jubilee Bridge flood gates have been opened and the Jubilee Bridge on Ferry Road in Thorne is now open. For a full list of roads that remain closed see the City of Doncaster Council website.
Our incident room remains open, and we are closely monitoring the forecast. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 21:00 PM on Thursday 26/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated properties near the River Lymn and Steeping
items.message: The rivers Lymn and Steeping have been falling steadily today, Wednesday 25th October. River levels remain above normal and are likely to remain high over the next few days.  There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days and the rivers will remain reactive to any future rainfall due to the saturated catchments. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings, and avoid contact with flood water. Do not walk on flood embankments and avoid riverside paths.

items.description: Isolated properties and villages in the west of the South Forty Foot Drain and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Forty Foot and west tributaries

items.message: South Forty Foot Drain and its tributaries have being falling steadily today, Wednesday 25th October and we do not expect any further flooding to properties. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days and the rivers will remain reactive to any future rainfall due to the saturated catchments.

This flood warning is no longer in force. River levels have continued to fall in the lower River Rother and there is no longer a threat of further flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Flooding has affected low-lying land near the watercourse, particularly in the Catcliffe area. Further showers are forecast over the next few days, though impacts are expected to be minimal. Our incident room remains open, and we are closely monitoring the forecast. Our operational staff have been on site in the Catcliffe and Treeton area, and will continue to monitor the situation today, 25/10/2023.

River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of Storm Babet. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are access roads and properties in Girton. The A1133 is closed and High Street is flooded, which isolating the village. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 26/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message: River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of Storm Babet. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services. Please avoid contact with flood water. Contact your insurance company if you've been flooded and take photographs of any flood damage. This message will be updated by 14:00 26/10/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of Storm Babet. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Collingham. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the week. Further showers are forecast over the next three days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid contact with flood water. Contact your insurance company if you've been flooded and take photographs of any flood damage. This message will be updated by 14:00 26/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, Old River Welland, Maxey Cut

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Welland has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels on Winestead Drain remain high due to rainfall associated with Storm Babet. Our duty officers are carrying out operations in the area, including pumping at Winestead Booster, and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are not expecting to require flood warnings in this area, but the pumping out of water is being slowed by high tides and levels remain high. Further rain showers are expected today which may prolong the high levels in the watercourses in this area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will update this message by 9PM 26/10/23.

River levels remain high following rainfall associated with Storm Babet, and are expected to remain high throughout Thursday 26th of October with further rain forecast.
